description: RadCase Teaching Case Archive - Classic Radiology Cases

cases.title: Tension Pneumothorax
cases.clinical_history: 45-year-old male presents to the ED after a motor vehicle collision. Patient is hypotensive, tachycardic, and in respiratory distress. Decreased breath sounds on the left.
cases.findings:
• Complete collapse of the left lung
• Mediastinal shift to the right
• Depression of the left hemidiaphragm
• Widening of the left intercostal spaces
• Tracheal deviation to the right
cases.teaching_points:
• Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis - do not delay treatment for imaging
• Key finding is mediastinal shift AWAY from the affected side
• Immediate needle decompression followed by chest tube is life-saving
• Differentiate from simple pneumothorax (no mediastinal shift)

cases.title: Pulmonary Embolism - Saddle Type
cases.clinical_history: 62-year-old female with sudden onset dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. Recent hip replacement surgery 2 weeks ago. D-dimer elevated at 4500 ng/mL.
cases.findings:
• Large filling defect straddling the main pulmonary artery bifurcation (saddle embolus)
• Extension into bilateral main pulmonary arteries
• Right heart strain: RV/LV ratio > 1.0
• Reflux of contrast into the IVC and hepatic veins
• Mosaic attenuation of lung parenchyma
cases.teaching_points:
• Saddle PE has high mortality - emergent consult for thrombolysis or embolectomy
• RV strain on CT predicts worse outcomes
• Wells criteria and D-dimer help stratify pre-test probability
• Look for DVT source - consider lower extremity venous ultrasound
• Window/level: mediastinal windows, ~100-300 HU width

cases.title: Acute Appendicitis
cases.clinical_history: 28-year-old male with 18 hours of periumbilical pain that has migrated to the right lower quadrant. Fever 38.2°C, WBC 14,000.
cases.findings:
• Dilated appendix measuring 12mm in diameter (normal <6mm)
• Appendiceal wall thickening and enhancement
• Periappendiceal fat stranding
• No extraluminal air or abscess
• Appendicolith present at the base
cases.teaching_points:
• Appendix >6mm with periappendiceal inflammation is diagnostic
• Appendicolith increases risk of perforation
• Look for secondary signs: cecal apical thickening, local lymphadenopathy
• Perforation signs: extraluminal air, abscess, phlegmon
• In women of childbearing age, consider ovarian pathology in differential

cases.title: Acute Ischemic Stroke - MCA Territory
cases.clinical_history: 72-year-old male with sudden onset right hemiparesis and aphasia. Symptoms began 2 hours ago. History of atrial fibrillation, not on anticoagulation.
cases.findings:
• Hyperdense left MCA sign (acute thrombus)
• Loss of gray-white differentiation in left insular cortex
• Subtle effacement of left sylvian fissure
• Loss of definition of left lentiform nucleus
• ASPECTS score: 7
cases.teaching_points:
• Early CT signs appear within 3-6 hours: hyperdense vessel, insular ribbon sign, loss of basal ganglia definition
• ASPECTS score helps quantify infarct extent (≥7 favorable for intervention)
• Window width 30-40 HU, center 30-40 HU to detect subtle changes
• CT angiography essential to identify occlusion site for thrombectomy
• Time is brain - door to needle <60 min for tPA

cases.title: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
cases.clinical_history: 55-year-old female with sudden onset 'worst headache of my life' followed by brief loss of consciousness. Now alert but photophobic with neck stiffness.
cases.findings:
• High-density blood in the basal cisterns (suprasellar, ambient, quadrigeminal)
• Blood in the Sylvian fissures bilaterally
• Extension into the interhemispheric fissure
• No hydrocephalus currently
• Modified Fisher Grade 3
cases.teaching_points:
• CT sensitivity for SAH decreases with time: 95% day 1, 50% day 7
• If CT negative but high clinical suspicion, perform lumbar puncture
• Pattern of blood can suggest aneurysm location (anterior communicating most common)
• CTA should follow to identify aneurysm
• Watch for complications: rebleeding, vasospasm, hydrocephalus

cases.title: Small Bowel Obstruction
cases.diagnosis: High-grade small bowel obstruction secondary to adhesions
cases.clinical_history: 68-year-old female with abdominal distension, vomiting, and obstipation for 2 days. History of hysterectomy 10 years ago. Last bowel movement 3 days ago.
cases.findings:
• Dilated small bowel loops (>3cm) with air-fluid levels
• Transition point in the right lower quadrant
• Decompressed distal small bowel and colon
• Small bowel feces sign proximal to obstruction
• No free air or bowel wall thickening to suggest ischemia
cases.teaching_points:
• 3-6-9 rule: small bowel >3cm, large bowel >6cm, cecum >9cm is dilated
• Adhesions are the most common cause of SBO in patients with prior surgery
• Transition point: where dilated bowel meets decompressed bowel
• Closed loop obstruction and strangulation require emergent surgery
• Signs of ischemia: decreased enhancement, pneumatosis, portal venous gas

cases.title: Aortic Dissection - Type A
cases.clinical_history: 58-year-old male with sudden onset tearing chest pain radiating to the back. History of poorly controlled hypertension. BP 180/110 mmHg, pulse deficit noted in left arm.
cases.findings:
• Intimal flap extending from the aortic root to the descending thoracic aorta
• True and false lumens identified with differential enhancement
• False lumen is larger and has slower flow
• Dissection extends into the left common carotid artery
• Moderate pericardial effusion concerning for hemopericardium
cases.teaching_points:
• Type A (involves ascending aorta) is a surgical emergency - mortality 1-2% per hour untreated
• Type B (descending only) typically managed medically unless complicated
• Look for malperfusion: coronary, cerebral, mesenteric, renal, limb
• Pericardial effusion suggests rupture - extremely high mortality
• ECG-gated CT helps reduce motion artifact at the root

cases.title: Lobar Pneumonia
cases.clinical_history: 45-year-old male smoker with 5 days of productive cough, fever, and right-sided pleuritic chest pain. Temperature 39°C, SpO2 92% on room air.
cases.findings:
• Dense airspace consolidation in the right lower lobe
• Air bronchograms visible within the consolidation
• Silhouetting of the right hemidiaphragm
• No significant pleural effusion
• No cavitation
cases.teaching_points:
• Silhouette sign helps localize: RLL silhouettes the diaphragm, RML silhouettes the right heart border
• Air bronchograms indicate airspace (not atelectatic) process
• Consider CT if: immunocompromised, not improving on antibiotics, suspected complication
• Follow-up imaging in 6-8 weeks to document resolution (especially in smokers to exclude mass)

cases.title: Renal Cell Carcinoma
cases.diagnosis: Left renal cell carcinoma with renal vein invasion
cases.clinical_history: 62-year-old male with incidentally discovered renal mass on ultrasound performed for unrelated abdominal pain. No hematuria. Mild flank discomfort.
cases.findings:
• 7cm heterogeneously enhancing mass arising from the left kidney
• Enhancement >20 HU between unenhanced and nephrographic phases
• Tumor thrombus extending into the left renal vein
• No IVC extension
• No lymphadenopathy or distant metastases
cases.teaching_points:
• Enhancement >20 HU is the key criterion for a solid renal mass
• Bosniak classification for cystic lesions (I, II, IIF, III, IV)
• Always evaluate the renal vein and IVC for tumor thrombus - affects surgical approach
• RCC spreads to lungs, bones, and brain - staging CT chest recommended
• Classic triad (hematuria, flank pain, palpable mass) seen in only 10%

cases.title: Pneumoperitoneum - Perforated Viscus
cases.clinical_history: 52-year-old male with sudden onset severe epigastric pain. Rigid abdomen on examination. History of NSAID use for chronic back pain. No prior abdominal surgery.
cases.findings:
• Large volume free intraperitoneal air
• Air tracking along the falciform ligament
• Focal discontinuity of the anterior duodenal wall
• Surrounding inflammatory changes in the periduodenal fat
• Small amount of free fluid in the pelvis
cases.teaching_points:
• Free air is best seen on CT with lung windows
• Upright CXR: air under the diaphragm (more on right due to liver providing contrast)
• Most common causes: perforated peptic ulcer, diverticulitis, appendicitis
• Rigler sign on plain film: both sides of bowel wall visible
• Emergent surgical consultation required

cases.title: Epidural Hematoma
cases.clinical_history: 22-year-old male brought in after assault with loss of consciousness. Had a 'lucid interval' before becoming increasingly drowsy. Left temporal scalp laceration noted.
cases.findings:
• Biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdense extra-axial collection in the left temporal region
• Does not cross suture lines
• Associated left temporal bone fracture
• 8mm midline shift to the right
• Effacement of the left lateral ventricle
cases.teaching_points:
• Biconvex shape is classic - dura stripped from calvarium
• 85% associated with skull fracture (usually middle meningeal artery)
• Lucid interval is classic history but only present in 20-50%
• Does NOT cross sutures (dura attached at sutures)
• Surgical emergency if: >30cc volume, >15mm thickness, >5mm midline shift, GCS <8

cases.title: Subdural Hematoma - Acute
cases.clinical_history: 78-year-old female on warfarin found unresponsive at home. INR 4.2. Unknown time of symptom onset. Evidence of head trauma.
cases.findings:
• Crescentic hyperdense extra-axial collection along the right cerebral convexity
• Crosses suture lines, limited by falx and tentorium
• 12mm thickness with 10mm midline shift
• Compression of the right lateral ventricle
• Uncal herniation with effacement of the suprasellar cistern
cases.teaching_points:
• Crescentic shape (concave toward brain) - follows brain surface
• Crosses sutures but NOT dural reflections (falx, tentorium)
• Elderly and anticoagulated patients at highest risk
• CT density changes with age: acute (hyperdense) → subacute (isodense) → chronic (hypodense)
• Anticoagulation reversal is critical - consult hematology

cases.title: Cholecystitis - Acute
cases.clinical_history: 48-year-old obese female with RUQ pain after eating, nausea, and fever. Positive Murphy's sign on examination. WBC 15,000.
cases.findings:
• Gallbladder wall thickening >3mm
• Pericholecystic fluid
• Multiple gallstones with posterior acoustic shadowing
• Stone impacted in the gallbladder neck
• Sonographic Murphy's sign positive
cases.teaching_points:
• Ultrasound is first-line imaging for suspected cholecystitis
• Sonographic Murphy sign: maximal tenderness when transducer presses on gallbladder
• HIDA scan if ultrasound equivocal (non-visualization of GB = cystic duct obstruction)
• Complications: gangrenous cholecystitis, perforation, emphysematous cholecystitis
• Acalculous cholecystitis in critically ill patients - high mortality

cases.title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm - Ruptured
cases.clinical_history: 72-year-old male with sudden severe abdominal and back pain. Hypotensive with BP 80/50. Known 5.5cm AAA on prior imaging, declined elective repair.
cases.findings:
• 7cm infrarenal aortic aneurysm with eccentric mural thrombus
• Discontinuity of the posterior aortic wall on the left
• Large retroperitoneal hematoma with active contrast extravasation
• Hematoma tracking into the left psoas muscle
• Draped aorta sign - posterior wall draped over spine
cases.teaching_points:
• Ruptured AAA has 80-90% mortality - immediate surgical/endovascular repair
• Classic triad: abdominal/back pain, pulsatile mass, hypotension (only 50% present)
• Contained rupture may be stable initially - can decompensate rapidly
• High-attenuating crescent sign indicates impending rupture
• Most ruptures are posterior/left posterolateral

cases.title: Pulmonary Nodule - Suspicious
cases.diagnosis: Suspicious pulmonary nodule - primary lung cancer
cases.clinical_history: 65-year-old male with 40 pack-year smoking history. Incidental 18mm pulmonary nodule found on CT performed for trauma. No prior imaging available.
cases.findings:
• 18mm spiculated solid nodule in the right upper lobe
• Pleural tail extending toward the major fissure
• No calcification or fat attenuation
• Adjacent ground-glass halo
• Mildly enlarged right hilar lymph node (12mm short axis)
cases.teaching_points:
• Spiculation, size >8mm, upper lobe location increase malignancy risk
• Fleischner Society guidelines for nodule follow-up based on size and risk
• PET-CT for nodules >8mm to assess metabolic activity
• Tissue diagnosis required before treatment - consider CT-guided biopsy vs bronchoscopy
• Lung-RADS for screening population nodule management

cases.title: Mesenteric Ischemia - Acute
cases.diagnosis: Acute superior mesenteric artery occlusion with bowel ischemia
cases.clinical_history: 76-year-old female with atrial fibrillation presenting with acute severe abdominal pain 'out of proportion to exam.' Pain began 6 hours ago after eating.
cases.findings:
• Filling defect in the proximal SMA consistent with embolus
• Decreased enhancement of multiple jejunal loops
• Bowel wall thickening with submucosal edema (target sign)
• Pneumatosis intestinalis in affected segments
• Portal venous gas
cases.teaching_points:
• 'Pain out of proportion to exam' is the classic clinical clue
• SMA embolism (usually cardiac source) vs SMA thrombosis (atherosclerotic)
• CT signs of ischemia: decreased enhancement, wall thickening, pneumatosis, portal venous gas
• Pneumatosis + portal venous gas = bowel necrosis, extremely high mortality
• Time sensitive - revascularization within 6-12 hours for viable bowel

cases.title: Diverticulitis - Acute Complicated
cases.clinical_history: 58-year-old male with 3 days of left lower quadrant pain, fever, and constipation. Temperature 38.5°C, WBC 18,000. Tender LLQ with guarding.
cases.findings:
• Multiple sigmoid diverticula with focal wall thickening
• 4cm rim-enhancing pericolic fluid collection (abscess)
• Pericolic fat stranding and fascial thickening
• No free air
• Mild proximal colonic dilatation
cases.teaching_points:
• CT is imaging modality of choice for suspected diverticulitis
• Hinchey classification guides management (I-IV based on complication severity)
• Abscess >3-4cm typically requires percutaneous drainage
• Avoid colonoscopy during acute episode - perform 6-8 weeks later
• 'Left-sided appendicitis' - but can occur anywhere in colon

cases.title: Ovarian Torsion
cases.diagnosis: Right ovarian torsion with underlying dermoid cyst
cases.clinical_history: 24-year-old female with sudden onset severe right lower quadrant pain and vomiting. Pain is intermittent and colicky. LMP 2 weeks ago, negative pregnancy test.
cases.findings:
• Enlarged right ovary (8cm) with heterogeneous echogenicity
• Peripheral follicles displaced to the cortex (string of pearls sign)
• 5cm complex cystic lesion with echogenic component and posterior shadowing (dermoid)
• Absent or reversed diastolic flow on Doppler
• Whirlpool sign of twisted vascular pedicle
cases.teaching_points:
• Ovarian torsion is a surgical emergency - ovarian salvage requires prompt surgery
• Risk factors: ovarian mass (especially dermoid), pregnancy, ovulation induction
• Doppler findings are not always reliable - absence of flow is specific but not sensitive
• Whirlpool sign is highly specific when present
• Clinical correlation crucial - if high suspicion, proceed to surgery even with normal Doppler

cases.title: Cervical Spine Fracture - Hangman's
cases.clinical_history: 45-year-old male in high-speed MVA with hyperextension mechanism. Complaining of neck pain. Neurologically intact. Cervical collar in place.
cases.findings:
• Bilateral pars interarticularis fractures of C2
• Anterior subluxation of C2 on C3 (5mm)
• Prevertebral soft tissue swelling
• C2-C3 disc space widening
• No evidence of vertebral artery injury on CTA
cases.teaching_points:
• Hangman's fracture = bilateral C2 pars fractures (traumatic spondylolisthesis)
• Levine-Edwards classification guides management
• Paradoxically, spinal canal widens with this fracture - neurologic injury uncommon
• Associated injuries common - evaluate entire spine
• CTA to evaluate vertebral arteries with C1-C2 injuries

cases.title: Liver Metastases
cases.diagnosis: Multiple hepatic metastases from colorectal cancer
cases.clinical_history: 62-year-old male with history of sigmoid colon adenocarcinoma resected 2 years ago. Presenting for surveillance imaging. CEA elevated at 45 ng/mL.
cases.findings:
• Multiple hypodense hepatic lesions ranging from 1-4cm
• Peripheral enhancement pattern on arterial phase
• Target-like appearance with central necrosis
• Lesions in both hepatic lobes (>4 segments involved)
• No extrahepatic metastatic disease
cases.teaching_points:
• Colorectal metastases are typically hypovascular (enhance less than liver)
• Hypervascular metastases: RCC, melanoma, carcinoid, thyroid, breast
• PET-CT useful for detecting extrahepatic disease and small lesions
• Hepatic metastasectomy can be curative in selected patients
• MRI with hepatobiliary contrast most sensitive for small lesions
